answers.answer: YOU are the person in control of your diabetes!  NOT your doctor.  You need to find a new doctor.  I moved to Lantus Insulin from pills.  I did not respond to the pills the way I felt I should and they gave me horrid side effects.  This is MY body and MY life.  No doctor can tell you that you CAN"T do that!  Do you have good control of the diabetes? What is the A1c?  On insulin - you adjust the eating and exercise to the insulin.  You must eat at certain times and you must take the insulin (especially Lantus) at the same time every day.  So, there are drawbacks.  However, you CAN increase the insulin to accomodate certain items (if you are on Regular insulin) such as a Birthday party where you would like a small slice of cake or a "football night" where you would like Pizza.  So it has its advantages.  You run the risk of having LOW blood sugar on insulin and you must check your sugar more often.  There are pros and cons.  Look into it and then find another doctor if this one won't work with you.Hope all goes well..

question: I would like to discuss with my doctor the possibility of moving to insulin to control my Type II diabetes. He won't have any of it. I hear I can have better control and fewer side effects. I can also adjust the medicine to my eating/exercise and not adjust the eating/exercise to my medication. Is this true.
title: Do i want insulin
